reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central move in the paper’s Section 2 argument: the illustrative “value is a product of many (roughly) independent factors” model used to motivate eutopian fragility and the claim that mostly-great futures are rare by default. If that independence-and-product story were badly wrong (e.g., strong positive correlations or common-cause institutional drivers), the specific inference from ‘many dimensions’ to ‘mostly-great is multiplicatively rare’ would be significantly weakened. However, the paper’s broader “no easy eutopia” conclusion is also supported by other strands (e.g., Section 3’s discussion of bounded/unbounded value functions and fussiness), so refuting the independence toy model would not collapse the whole position. The objection is conceptually sound and clearly stated, but it remains somewhat underdeveloped: it asserts plausible coupling without showing (i) that correlations would be strong enough to make mostly-great futures common under reasonable distributions, or (ii) that the relevant dimensions are in fact governed by shared institutions in a way that persists through drastic regime changes (e.g., space expansion, digital minds, lock-in). It’s relevant to Forethought’s agenda because it bears directly on a Tier-2 working assumption they lean on (multiplicative/product-of-factors framing) and suggests a concrete robustness check (model correlated factors / common-cause competence), though it doesn’t yet deliver a decisive refutation.
title: "Interdependent Moral Dimensions Undermine Fragility"
